rubric.requirements: The paper "APT: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning Pretrained Language Models for Efficient Training and Inference" has been reproduced

sub_tasks.requirements: The required pre-trained models, datasets, and metrics are available
The required pre-trained models are available
Code has been implemented such that RoBERTa can be loaded into memory
Code has been implemented such that T5, specifically t5-lm-adapt, can be loaded into memory
The required pre-trained datasets have been setup
Code for accessing the train and dev splits from the SST2 dataset from the GLUE benchmark has been implemented
Code for accessing the train and dev splits from the MNLI dataset from the GLUE benchmark has been implemented
Code for accessing the train and dev splits from the SQuAD 2.0 benchmark has been implemented
Code for accessing the train and test sets from the CNN Dailymail (CNN/DM) dataset has been implemented
The required dataset-specific metrics have been implemented
When evaluating models on SST2 and MNLI, the dev set accuracy is reported
When evaluating models on SQuAD, the dev set F1 score is reported
When evaluating models on CNN/DM, the ROUGE 1/2/L scores on the test set are reported
Training and evaluation metrics have been implemented
For each method trained on some dataset, the train time is measured as the time-to-accuracy of reaching 97% of the dev (/test) set performance of the finetuning baseline
For each method, when being trained on some dataset, code has been implemented to record the max GPU memory utilization, using torch.cuda.max_memory_allocated() (or equivalent)
For each method, when being evaluated on some dataset, the speed of inference is measured as the inference throughput (sampled processed per second)
For each method, when performing inference with some dataset, code has been implemented to record the max GPU memory utilization, using torch.cuda.max_memory_allocated() (or equivalent)
LoRA has correctly been setup
LoRA is available to be applied to modules within transformers
After training a method using LoRA adapters, before performing inference, the LoRA parameters are merged into the parameters of the model
The baselines have been implemented
The fine-tuning baseline is implemented by finetuning a pre-trained model on a dataset
The Mask Tuning baseline is implemented, using the implementation at https://github.com/WoosukKwon/retraining-free-pruning
The LoRA+Prune baseline is implemented by first finetuning a model with LoRA adapters, then applying Mask Tuning
In LoRA+Prune, LoRA adapters are first added to modules of the given model
In LoRA+Prune, the model with the LoRA adapters added is finetuned
In LoRA+Prune, once the model with LoRA adapters has finished finetuning, Mask Tuning is applied to the model
The CoFi baseline (also named "Prune+Distill" in Section 5.2) is implemented, using the implementation at https://github.com/princeton-nlp/CoFiPruning
The LoRA+Prune+Distill baseline is implemented
In LoRA+Prune+Distill, LoRA adapters are first added to modules of the given model

In LoRA+Prune+Distill, CoFi pruning and distillation is used but with LoRA parameters only; only the $L_0$ modules (the non-negative stochastic gates in CoFi which collectively determine which weights to set to zero) and LoRA parameters are tuneable
APT has been implemented
The APT adapter architecture has been implemented, following Section 4.1
The masked input to the adapter is computed
The masked input to the APT adapter is computed as $X \circ m_i$, where $X$ is the input to the adapter and is $m_i \in \mathbb{R}^d_i$ a learnable binary pruning mask
When APT is applied to MHA layers, $m_i$ prunes the transformers' hidden dimension
When APT is applied to FFN layers, $m_i$ prunes the transformers' hidden dimension
The new weight matrix is computed, using the original weight matrix $W \in \mathbb{R}^{d_o \times d_i}$
For the APT adapter implementation, a dynamic rank $r_{apt}$ is defined for each weight matrix, which can vary
For the APT adapter implementation, a new learnable weight matrix $W_A \in \mathbb{R}^{r_{apt} \times d_i}$ is defined
For the APT adapter implementation, a new learnable weight matrix $W_B \in \mathbb{R}^{d_o \times r_{apt}}$ is defined
For the APT adapter implementation, the original weight matrix $W$ is kept frozen; it isn't updated during training
For the APT adapter implementation, the new weight matrix is computed as $W + 2 \cdot W_B W_A$
For the APT adapter implementation, the new weight matrix is multipled by the masked input
The output of the APT adapter is correctly computed
For the APT adapter implementation, the output of the multiplication between the updated weights and masked input is masked by a learnable binary pruning mask $m_o \mathbb{R}^d_o$
When the APT adapter is applied to MHA layers, $m_o$ prunes attention heads
When the APT adapter is applied to FFN layers, $m_o$ prunes internal neurons in the FFN layers
Outlier-aware salience score is implemented, following equations 3 and 9
For a parameter $W_{i,j}$ that is not in an APT adapter layer, the salience is computed as $S(W_{i,j}) = \left| W_{i,j} \cdot \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial W_{i,j}} \right|$
For an APT adapter layer, the salience is computed following equation 9 as the sum of the block-wise frozen weight salience and the corresponding tuning weight

Outlier-aware salience for a block is computed as $\hat{S}(W_{:,j}) = \tilde{S}(W_{:,j}) + \left( \text{Kurt}(O_{j,:}) \right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$, where $\tilde{S}$ is the salience score, $O_{:,j} = W_{:,j} \circ X_{j,:}^T$ represents the activation, and $\text{Kurt}(\cdot)$ stands for Kurtosis

During training, the outlier-aware salience of each block is computed as an exponential moving-average $\overline{S}^{(t)}(m) \gets 0.85 \overline{S}^{(t-1)}(m) + 0.15 \hat{S}(m)$, where $\overline{S}^{(t)}(m)$ is the moving-average of block $m$ at time step $t$, and $\hat{S}(m)$ is the current outlier-aware salience score of block $m$
Low-cost Adaptive LM Pruning is implemented, as described in Section 4.2 and Appendix B
APT Blocks are sorted in descending order by salience density
Computing the parameter count for different blocks is implemented correctly following equations 10, 11, 12
Given a hidden dimensionality $d_m$ and number of attention heads $n_h$, the number of parameters of a MHA head is computed as $4 \times d_m \times d_m / n_h$
Given a hidden dimensionality $d_m$, the number of parameters of a FFN neuron is computed as $2 \times d_m$

Given a hidden dimensionality $d_m$, number of layers $n_L$, and number of neurons in the FFN layer $n_f$, the number of parameters associated with a transformers hidden dimension across all layers is computed as $n_L \times (4 d_m + 2 n_f)$
For a block with salience $S$ and number of parameters $\mathcal{C}$, the salience density is computed as the salience divided by the parameter number $S / \mathcal{C}$
The salience density is only calculated for blocks that have an APT adapter applied to them
The salience density of each block is re-computed everytime the number of parameters of the model changes
The blocks are sorted by their salience density in descending order
A function $f$ for identifying a block's category is implemented, following equation 13. $f$ returns 0 when block $b_i$ is a head, 1 if $b_i$ is a neuron, and 2 if $b_i$ is a dimension
Following equation 14, given any index $i$, the parameter number of the LM consisting of the top-$i$ blocks can be computed

Following equation 14, given any index $i$ and a sorted list of N blocks in descending order of salience density, the number of blocks in the top-$i$ blocks that are added to heads is computed as $n_h^\prime = \sum_{j=0}^{i-1} \delta (0, f(b_j))$, where $\delta (i, j)$ is the Kronecker delta function that returns 1 if $i=j$, and otherwise 0, and $f$ is the function that returns 0 when block $b_i$ is a head, 1 if $b_i$ is a neuron, and 2 if $b_i$ is a dimension

Following equation 14, given any index $i$ and a sorted list of N blocks in descending order of salience density, the number of blocks in the top-$i$ blocks that are added to neurons is computed as $n_f^\prime = \sum_{j=0}^{i-1} \delta (1, f(b_j))$, where $\delta (i, j)$ is the Kronecker delta function that returns 1 if $i=j$, and otherwise 0, and $f$ is the function that returns 0 when block $b_i$ is a head, 1 if $b_i$ is a neuron, and 2 if $b_i$ is a dimension

Following equation 14, given any index $i$ and a sorted list of N blocks in descending order of salience density, the number of blocks in the top-$i$ blocks that are added to dimensions is computed as $d_m^\prime = \sum_{j=0}^{i-1} \delta (2, f(b_j))$, where $\delta (i, j)$ is the Kronecker delta function that returns 1 if $i=j$, and otherwise 0, and $f$ is the function that returns 0 when block $b_i$ is a head, 1 if $b_i$ is a neuron, and 2 if $b_i$ is a dimension

Following equation 14, given any index $i$ and a sorted list of N blocks in descending order of salience density, the parameter number is computed as $C_{\text{top}-i} = (4d_h^\prime \cdot n_h^\prime + 2n_f^\prime) \cdot d_m^\prime$, where $d_h^\prime$ is the number of heads in the model, $n_h^\prime$ is the number of the top-$i$ blocks that are added to heads, $n_f^\prime$ is the number of the top-$i$ blocks that are added to neurons, and $d_m^\prime$ is the number of the top-$i$ blocks that are added to dimensions
In Low-cost Adaptive LM Pruning, binary search is used to get the top-$i$ salient blocks
In Low-cost Adaptive LM Pruning, blocks that are marked to be pruned have their corresponding masks decreased by 0.01
Adaptive and Efficient LM Tuning is implemented, as described in Section 4.3

In Adaptive and Efficient LM Tuning, given an APT adapter $H_{apt}$, the importance score is computed as $\mathcal{I}(H_{apt}) = \sum_{i,j} S(W_{Bi,j})$, the summation of the parameter salience scores in $W_B$ (where $W_B \in \mathbb{R}^{d_o \times r_{apt}}$ is an APT tuning parameter)
In Adaptive and Efficient LM Tuning, APT adapters are sorted by their importance score
The ranks of the top-half blocks (blocks with largest importance) is linearly increased

When increasing tuning parameter from $\Delta t$ to $Delta t^{\prime}$, the salient layer's rank is changed from $r_{apt}$ to $r_{apt}^\prime=\lfloor{r_{apt} \cdot \frac{\Delta_t^\prime}{\Delta_t }\rfloor$

When adding parameters, random Gaussian initialized parameters $\mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)$ are concatenated to $W_A$, and zeros are concatenated to $W_B$, where $W_A \in \mathbb{R}^{r_{apt} \times d_i}$,  $W_B \in \mathbb{R}^{d_o \times r_{apt}}$ are both APT tuning parameters
Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation is implemented, as described in Section 4.4

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, at each training epoch, intermediate layers from the teacher model are randomly selected for distillation; 4 teacher layers are randomly sampled in each quarter slice of the layers (e.g. for a 12-layer network the slices would be: 0-2, 3-5, 6-8, 9-11)
In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, the teacher-student layer-mapping function $m(\cdot)$ is implemented correctly

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, the teacher-student layer-mapping function $m(\cdot)$ is implemented to match 4 teacher layers with the closest, non-pruned student layers, using the same method introduced in CoFi (Xia et al., 2022). For each of the 4 teacher layers, the layer mapping function dynamically determines which of the student layers is closest; $\mathop{\arg \min}\limits_{j:\mathbf{z}_{FFN}^{(j)}>0} \text{MSE} (W_{\text{layer}} H_s^j, H_t^i)$, where $H_s^j, H_t^i$ are hidden representations from the $j$-th student FFN layer and $i$-th teacher layer respectively, and $W_{\text{layer}} \in \mathbb{R}^{d\timesd}$ is a learnable linear transformation matrix, initialized as an identity matrix
In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, the teacher-student layer-mapping function $m(\cdot)$ is re-computed every training step

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, the hidden layer distillation loss is defined as $\mathcal{L}_{\text{layer}} = \sum_{i=1}^4 \text{MSE}(\text{Tr}(H_s^{\phi(i)}), H_t^i)$, where $\text{Tr}$ denotes the tunable LoRA layer for layer transformation, initialized as an identical matrix $\mathcal{I}$, and $\phi(\cdot)$ is the teacher-student layer-mapping function
In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, $\mu$ is a moving term that linearly scales from 0 to 1 during pruning
The distillation loss $L_{\text{distil}}$ is implemented

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, cross-entropy loss between the pruned student's and teacher's output probability distributions $\mathbf{p}_s$ and $\mathbf{p}_t$ is computed as $\mathcal{L}_{\text{pred}} = D_{\text{KL}}(\mathbf{p}_s \,\|\, \mathbf{p}_t)$

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, when training on GLUE tasks, the layer distillation is combined with the prediction-layer distillation: $\mathcal{L}_{\text{distill}} = \mathcal{L}_{\text{pred}} + 0.9 \mathcal{L}_{\text{layer}}$

In Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation, when training on SQuAD or CNN/DM, the layer distillation is combined with the prediction-layer distillation: $\mathcal{L}_{\text{distill}} = 0.1 \mathcal{L}_{\text{pred}} + 0.9 \mathcal{L}_{\text{layer}}$

Following equation 7, the distillation objective is defined as $\mathcal{L} = \mu \mathcal{L}_{\text{distill}} + (1 - \mu) \mathcal{L}_{\text{ft}}$, where $\mathcal{L}_{ft}$ is the supervised fine-tuning objective

When pruning LMs with APT, the LM is first pruned and trained with the self-distillation objective for some pre-defined number of epochs, then it is fine-tuned on the same dataset for some other pre-defined number of epochs

When pruning LMs with APT, given a pre-determined target sparsity $\gamma_T$ and total number of pruning training steps $T$, the target sparsity at timestep $t$ is computed by $\gamma_t = \gamma_T + (1 - \gamma_T) \left(1 - \frac{t}{T}\right)^3$
After training a model using APT adapters, before performing inference, the APT parameters are merged into the parameters of the model
The recorded metrics show that the results in section 5 have been reproduced

The SQuAD hyperparameters are configured

All models trained on SQuAD use a batch size of 32

The Finetune method is trained for 10 epochs
The LoRA and APT adapters are applied to the correct modules of RoBERTa and T5

rubric.requirements: The paper "All-in-one simulation-based inference" has been reproduced.

sub_tasks.requirements: Variance Exploding SDE (VESDE) is implemented, as described in A2.1
The drift term for Variance Exploding SDE is defined as $f(x, t)=0$
The diffusion term for Variance Exploding SDE is defined as $g(t)=\sigma_{min} \cdot (\frac{\sigma_{max}}{\sigma_{min}})^t \cdot \sqrt{2 \log \frac{\sigma_{max}}{\sigma_{min}}}$

The perturbation kernel for the Variance Exploding SDE is defined as $p(x_t|x_0) = \mathcal{N}(x_t, x_t, \sigma(t)I)$ where $\sigma(t) = \sigma_{min}^2\left( \frac{\sigma_{max}}{\sigma_{min}} \right)^{2t}$
The constant $\sigma_{max}$ for VESDE is set to 15
The constant $\sigma_{min}$ for VESDE is set to 0.0001
In VESDE, samples are drawn from the time interval [1e-5, 1]
The Simformer model, training process and inference process has been implemented
The Simformer architecture and tokenizer has been implemented
The tokenizer for the Simformer has been implemented
The tokenizer correctly tokenizes and embeds the identifiers
Each unique variable has an integer identifier. Multiple observations of the same variable share the same identifier
The tokenizer uses learnable vector embeddings to embed each identifier

The embedding for a single value is created by repeating the scalar value to match the desired dimensionality. For example, to embed the value 1 to desired dimensionality N, we would have a vector [1, 1, ...., 1] of length N

The tokenizer correctly tokenizes and embeds the metadata (if required); the tokenizer applies a learnable linear mapping of a random Fourier embedding of the elements in the index set to the desired dimensionality.

The tokenizer uses learnable vector embeddings to embed each value in a condition state - "True" values are mapped to a shared learnable vector embedding, whereas "False" values are mapped to zeros (of the desired dimensionality)
For each input, the tokenizer concatenates the embeddings of the identifier, value, metadata (if used), and condition state in that order

The tokenizer takes inputs: a sequence of scalar values, a sequence of integer variable identifiers, a condition mask $M_C$, and optional metadata if required. It embeds these inputs into a sequence of tokens, each of equal dimensionality
The Simformer architecture has been implemented

The Simformer model is a slightly modified vanilla encoder-only transformer following the implementation proposed by (Vaswani et al., 2017). The only modification is that the decoder is a single linear layer that produces a single scalar score for each variable token in the input sequence. The Simformer model is described in Section 3, Figure 2, and Appendix A.1
Diffusion time is embedded as a random Gaussian Fourier embedding, and a linear projection of diffusion time is added to the output of each feed-forward block in the transformer

The Simformer takes inputs: the diffusion time $t$, a sequence of tokens from the tokenizer, and an attention mask. These are projected to a sequence of scalar outputs, representing the marginal scores of the diffusion process at time $t$.
The condition and attention masks are correctly computed for each sample passed to the Simformer

During training, for each training sample, the condition mask $M_C$ is randomly sampled as either 1) the joint distribution, where $M_C=[0, 0, ..., 0]$, 2) the posterior distribution where data variables are observed and parameters are unobserved, 3) the likelihood function where data variables are unobserved and parameter variables are observed, 4) a Bernoulli distribution with p=0.3 (resampled for each element), 5) a Bernoulli distribution with p=0.7 (resampled for each element)
The attention mask $M_E$ is correctly computed for each sample passed to the Simformer
$M_E$ is selected to be undirected, directed, or fully dense
If $M_E$ is selected to be fully dense, every token is allowed to attend to every other token
The attention mask $M_E$ is correctly computed for the undirected and directed cases

For both undirected and directed cases, the attention mask $M_E$ is computed to capture the known dependencies of the current task. Specifically, each task provides $M_E$ as given by the adjacency matrix of a directed/undirected graphical model with the diagonal set to True.

If $M_E$ is directed it must be updated for a given $M_C$. The algorithm proposed by Webb at al. (2018) is used to add the minimal number of edges required to represent additional dependencies from conditioning as specified in $M_C$
The code for training the Simformer model has been implemented

When training the Simformer, for each training sample $\hat{x}_0$, the noise level $t$ is sampled in the range [1e-5, 1] to generate a (partially) noisy sample $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_t^{M_C} = (1 - M_C) \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}_t + M_C \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}_0$ i.e. variables that we want to condition on remain clean.
The loss function for the Simformer is correctly defined

A diffusion model loss is used that targets (un)conditional marginal score $\nabla_{\mathbf{x}_t^{\text{unobserved}}}\,\log p_t(\mathbf{x}_t^{\text{unobserved}} \mid \mathbf{x}^{\text{observed}})$ as defined by the condition mask $M_C$ and p(x).

As defined in Section 3.3, for each (partially) noisy training sample $\hat{x}_t^{M_c}$, the Simformer loss is defined as: $\ell(\phi, M_C, t, \hat{\mathbf{x}}_0, \hat{\mathbf{x}}_t) = (1-M_C)\cdot \left(s_\phi^{M_E}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_t^{M_C}, t) - \nabla_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}_t} \log p_t(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_t|\hat{\mathbf{x}}_0)\right)$, where $s_\phi^{M_E}$ denotes the score model equipped with a specific attention mask $M_E$
The Simformer loss is only computed over samples that are unobserved, i.e., they have a value of 0 in $M_C$

The total Simformer loss per mini-match is given by a weighted sum, as given by a positive weighting function $\lambda(t)$ e.g. $\lambda(t)=g(t)^2$ where $g(t)$ is the diffusion coefficient of the VESDE.
Code for sampling arbitrary conditionals from a trained Simformer model has been implemented
When performing inference using Simformer, the reverse diffusion process is run on all unobserved variables. Observed variables are kept constant at their initial values
Euler-Maruyama discretization has been implemented to run the diffusion process backward
Euler-Maruyama discretization has been implemented to run the diffusion process backward for Simformer

The Simformer supports conditioning on intervals.
Algorithm 1 has been implemented such that conditioning on intervals can optionally be selected

For conditioning on intervals, the self-recurrence is implemented such that a mutable hyperparameter $r$ specifies how many times future points undergo a forward diffusion step followed by a reverse step, incrementally refining each sample.
For conditioning on intervals, the constraint function is defined as $c(\hat{x}) = \hat{x} - u$, where $u$ is a mutable hyperparameter
For conditioning on intervals, the scaling function $s(t)$ is defined as $s(t)=\frac{1}{\sigma(t)^2)|$, i.e., inversely proportional to the variance
Algorithm 1 has been fully implemented to sample from conditions specified by the constraint function.
Conditioning on intervals can optionally be used when sampling

Each method NPE, NRE, and NLE is trained using the provided training loop (e.g. sbi.SNPE().train())
Each method NPE, NRE and NLE uses a batch size of 1000

rubric.requirements: The core contributions of the paper "Batch and match: black-box variational inference with a score-based divergence" have been reproduced.

sub_tasks.requirements: The core variational inference algorithms studied in the paper have been implemented
The Batch and Match (BaM) algorithm for Variational Inference (VI) has been implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

BaM has been implemented such that, at minimum, it takes batch size, inverse regularization (learning rate), the target score function, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.
The 'batch' step from BaM has been correctly implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration the current estimated mean and covariance matrix are used to sample $z_b$ from a Gaussian for $b = 1, \dots, B$, where B is the batch size.

The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration the "score" ($\nabla \log (p)$, where $p$ is the density of the target distribution)) can be and is computed for each sampled $z_b$.
The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that the sample statistics are accumulated following equations (6) and (7), as shown in step 5 of Algorithm 1.
The 'match' step from BaM has been correctly implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

The 'match' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration, the U and V matrices have been implemented using the accumulated statistics from the 'batch' step, as outlined in equations (10) and (11) and in step 6 of Algorithm 1.

The 'match' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration, the U and V matrices are used along with the accumulated statistics and the inverse regularization (learning rate) to update the estimated mean and covariance using equations (12) and (13) as shown in step 7 of algorithm 1.
The BaM 'match' step has been implemented such that it optionally supports updating covariance using the update in Lemma B.3, asserting that B<D
BaM has been implemented such that it generally follows the steps in Algorithm 1.
Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) has been implemented as outlined in the provided Algorithm 2 code snippet, supporting a Gaussian variational approximation with full covariance.

ADVI is implemented such that, at minimum, it takes batch size, a learning rate or learning rate schedule, the unnormalized target log density, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.

ADVI has been implemented such that at each iteration, a mini-batch of samples is drawn from the current approximate distribution $q_{t}$, a Gaussian with some mean $\mu_{t}$ and covariance $\Sigma_{t}$.

ADVI has been implemented such that at each iteration, a stochastic estimate of the (negative) Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) is computed using the reparameterization trick or an equivalent approach for samples \(z_b\sim q_{t}\). Specifically, the code forms \(-\sum_b [\log p(z_b) - \log q_t(z_b)]\).

ADVI has been implemented such that the gradient of the negative ELBO (with respect to the variational parameters) is used to update the variational parameters (e.g. via the Adam optimizer) as shown in step 5 of Algorithm 2
Overall, the implemented ADVI procedure follows the logic of Algorithm 2

Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) "Score" variant has been implemented, such that it is identical to the ADVI implementation but rather than using ELBO loss, it uses score-based divergence.

Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) "Fisher" variant has been implemented, such that it is identical to the ADVI implementation but rather than using ELBO loss, it uses Fisher divergence
The Gaussian Score Matching (GSM) approach for Variational Inference (VI) has been implemented as described in Algorithm 3, supporting a Gaussian variational approximation with full covariance.

GSM has been implemented such that it takes, at minimum, a batch size, the unnormalized target density, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.

GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, a mini-batch of samples is drawn from the current approximate distribution $q_{t}$, a Gaussian with some mean $\mu_{t}$ and covariance $\Sigma_{t}$.
GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, for each sampled $z_b$ the target distribution's score \$s_b = \nabla \log \tilde{p}(z_b)$ is computed
GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, for each sampled $z_b$, the updated for mean and covariance are estimated following steps 6 and 7 of Algorithm 3.
GSM has been implemented such that each iteration, the variational mean and covariance are updated following step 9 of Algorithm 3.
Overall, the GSM procedure has been implemented so that it follows the main steps of Algorithm 3.
The results of section 5.1 have been replicated
Code has been implemented for measuring the forward and reverse empirical KL divergences between two distributions
The results of Figure 5.1 and Figure E.3 have been replicated

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated Gaussian distributions measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that BaM converges orders of magnitude earlier (in terms of number of iterations) than ADVI.

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated Gaussian distributions measured over VI iterations for BaM and GSM show the two methods perform similarly for B=2, while BaM at larger batch sizes tends to converge more quickly than GSM at B=2.

The forward and reverse KL divergence measured between target and estimated Gaussian distributions over VI iterations for the gradient based methods (ADVI, ADVI (Score) and ADVI (Fisher)) show that the three methods perform similarly

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with normal tails ($t=1$) and varying skews measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that BaM converges faster (in terms of number of iterations) than ADVI.

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with normal tails ($t=1$) and varying skews measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that, compared to ADVI, BaM converges to a higher value in terms of forward KL divergence and to a similar value in terms of reverse KL divergence

The reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM, GSM, ADVI, Score and Fisher show that all methods converge to similar values

The reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM, GSM and ADVI show that in some cases, BaM and ADVI converge to better values than GSM

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that BaM typically converges in fewer iterations than ADVI

The results of Figure 5.3 and of Figure E.6 have been replicated

The relative mean error between HMC and estimated PosteriorDB problem posteriors measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show BaM outperforms ADVI, converging earlier (in terms of number of iterations) to lower relative mean errors.
The relative mean error between HMC and estimated PosteriorDB problem posteriors measured over VI iterations for BaM and GSM show that GSM can converge faster than BaM for smaller batch sizes.

The relative mean error between HMC and estimated PosteriorDB problem posteriors measured over VI iterations for BaM, ADVI and GSM show that in general BaM tends to benefit from larger batch sizes, while ADVI and GSM do not.

The relative mean error and relative standard error between HMC and estimated PosteriorDB problem posteriors measured over VI iterations for BaM, ADVI and GSM show that in general the same trends can be observed for relative mean error and relative standard error, with the exception of the "hierarchical" `eight-schools-centered` problem where BaM converges to a higher relative standard error than GSM or ADVI.

The results of Figure 5.4 b) from Section 5.3 have been replicated

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM at batch size 10 shows that BaM performs poorly (MSE greater than 0.2) at smaller batch sizes, i.e. at a batch size of 10.

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM at batch sizes 100 and 300 show that BaM performs competitively (MSE less than 0.05) at larger batch sizes, i.e. at a batch size of 100 and 300.

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM, GSM and ADVI at batch size 300 show that BaM converges an order of magnitude (or more) faster (in terms of taking less iterations to converge) than ADVI and GSM

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM, ADVI and AVI at batch sizes 10, 100 and 300 show that in general either BaM or ADVI or both achieve a MSE than AVI.
